unnormalised: ## Streamlining Your Travel with Unique Identifiers: A Quick Guide
normalised: ## Streamlining Your Travel with Unique Identifiers: A Quick Guide

unnormalised: Planning a trip, whether it's a short getaway or a long-awaited vacation, involves managing a plethora of details. From flight bookings to hotel reservations, keeping track of all the confirmation numbers and identifiers can feel overwhelming. Let's break down some common travel identifiers and how to use them effectively, so you can travel stress-free.
normalised: Planning a trip, whether it is a short getaway or a long awaited vacation, involves managing a plethora of details. From flight bookings to hotel reservations, keeping track of all the confirmation numbers and identifiers can feel overwhelming. Let us break down some common travel identifiers and how to use them effectively, so you can travel stress free.

unnormalised: First, there's the ever-important PNR, or Passenger Name Record. This is a 6-character alphanumeric code (like "AX52YZ") generated by the airline's reservation system. It acts as a reference number for your flight booking. You'll find your PNR on your flight ticket or confirmation email. When checking in online or at the airport kiosk, you can use your PNR to retrieve your booking details. Airlines like Indigo or Air India often use the PNR to help locate your reservation.
normalised: First, there is the ever important P-N-R, or Passenger Name Record. This is a six character alphanumeric code (like "A-X-five-two-Y-Z") generated by the airline's reservation system. It acts as a reference number for your flight booking. You will find your P-N-R on your flight ticket or confirmation email. When checking in online or at the airport kiosk, you can use your P-N-R to retrieve your booking details. Airlines like Indigo or Air India often use the P-N-R to help locate your reservation.

If you need to make changes to your booking, providing the ticket number (e.g., 1234567890123) alongside your PNR might be necessary.

It is a unique identifier assigned to each individual ticket and is separate from the P-N-R, which can group multiple tickets together. If you need to make changes to your booking, providing the ticket number (e.g., one two three four five six seven eight nine zero one two three) alongside your P-N-R might be necessary.

unnormalised: Hotel booking confirmations also come with their own identifiers. You'll usually find a "confirmation number" or "reservation ID" (like "GH789012") on the hotel booking confirmation you receive via email. This number is essential for check-in and any communication with the hotel, such as the Taj Mahal Hotel in Mumbai. Remember to keep these readily accessible.
normalised: Hotel booking confirmations also come with their own identifiers. You will usually find a "confirmation number" or "reservation I-D" (like "G-H-seven-eight-nine-zero-one-two") on the hotel booking confirmation you receive via email. This number is essential for check in and any communication with the hotel, such as the Taj Mahal Hotel in Mumbai. Remember to keep these readily accessible.

unnormalised: For train travel in India, IRCTC provides a transaction ID along with your PNR number. If you book your train ticket through IRCTC, make sure you note your PNR no. and the transaction ID, like "TXN12345678". You can use either of these to check your reservation status on the IRCTC website or app. If you book in person, the ticket itself will contain a 10-digit PNR number that is unique to your travel journey.

If you book your train ticket through I-R-C-T-C, make sure you note your P-N-R no. and the transaction I-D, like "T-X-N-one-two-three-four-five-six-seven-eight". You can use either of these to check your reservation status on the I-R-C-T-C website or app. If you book in person, the ticket itself will contain a ten digit P-N-R number that is unique to your travel journey.

unnormalised: Finally, don't forget about travel insurance policies. Your policy document will feature a unique policy number (e.g., "INS2024/001234") and can be used to track your insurance. Keeping these identifiers safe, accessible, and distinct from other documents will make your journeys easier. Knowing what they are and how to use them will ensure smooth travel experiences.
